title: Searching for the Past in Cameroon, Only to Find It Is Still Very Present
description: Patrice Nganang’s trilogy of historical novels explores his country’s national identity, rife with great promise and pain. “The dream of Cameroon is contradictory,” he says.
content: Patrice Nganang traveled for weeks in the countryside of western Cameroon in 2017, doing research for the final novel of his monumental trilogy about his country’s fraught history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Benediction’ Review: A Poet’s Life, in Love and War
description: Terence Davies’s latest film is a biography of Siegfried Sassoon, whose writing about World War I changed British literature.
content: Since his first feature, “Distant Voices, Still Lives” in 1988, the British writer and director Terence Davies has made a handful of films that can be described — owing to their emotional subtlety and formal precision — as poetic. Recently, he has been making films about poets, which isn’t quite the same thing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: Inside the Audition for Democrats’ Next Crusading Attorney General
description: In cerulean-blue Massachusetts, candidates for the state’s top law enforcement job are seeking to demonstrate their faith in progressive ideals. But the race could be decided on other grounds.
content: Want to know where Democratic politics are headed? Watch Massachusetts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: A Medical Worker Rushed to Escape From a ‘Labyrinth’ of Offices in Tulsa
description: Gannon Gill said the sound of gunfire interrupted an appointment with a patient. He led his patient to safety after a deadly shooting at a medical facility in Tulsa, Okla.
content: [Go here for updates on the Tulsa medical center shooting.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: In Photos: Queen Elizabeth II Celebrates Her Platinum Jubilee
description: The royal family gathered at Buckingham Palace to kick off a joyful commemorative weekend marking Elizabeth II’s 70 years as queen.
content: Britain is awash in pomp and pageantry for the Platinum Jubilee, a four-day celebration of Queen Elizabeth’s seven decades on the throne, with street festivals, lunch parties and even an occasional glimpse of the queen herself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman and Sarah Blesener
title: As the Baby Formula Shortage Drags On, Moms Are Pumping for the Cause
description: New York mothers with an excess supply of breast milk are donating to milk banks, as well as through informal channels, to help parents struggling to feed their babies amid the crisis.
content: Diana Feng, a mother in Douglaston, Queens, spent weeks this spring caught up in the frenzy of the ongoing infant formula shortage, refreshing store websites and asking friends to help her track down the Similac formula she needed to feed her 5-month-old daughter, Charlotte.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Friday Briefing: Russia Has Seized One-Fifth of Ukraine
description: Plus South Korea’s conservatives win big and the queen celebrates 70 years on the throne.
content: Nearly 100 days into Russia’s war in Ukraine, during which Ukraine’s army has surpassed expectations and repelled its much larger foe out of major cities, President Volodymyr Zelensky said on Thursday that Russia now occupied one-fifth of the country — roughly the size of the Netherlands. Zelensky also accused Russia of forcibly deporting more than 200,000 Ukrainian children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: A Judy Baca Moment: ‘My Work Has Been Good for a Long Time’
description: Hailed for her rich depictions of California history and social struggle, the Chicana artist says the attention, after decades of being overlooked, surprises her.
content: LOS ANGELES — It has never been easy to see a Judith Baca mural. They are scattered around this city, splashes of color and depictions of triumph and trauma hidden alongside highways, alleyways and river banks. And they were even harder to paint. Baca had to overcome fumes from traffic whizzing by on the 110 Freeway (she brought a tank of oxygen for when her legs began feeling heavy), flash floods in the Tujunga Wash, and 112-degree afternoons in the San Fernando Valley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Summer TV 2022: 27 Shows to Watch
description: Viewers can travel from Westeros to Middle-earth and everywhere in between in a season that shows no sign of a slowdown.
content: The recent travails of Netflix, and the tech sector in general, have served notice that the abundance of new series that you have gotten used to — and perhaps grown tired of — may not last forever. But if it turns out that this summer represented the beginning of the end, it will have been an impressive going-away party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Matt Richtel
title: A Disturbing New Pattern in Mass Shootings: Young Assailants
description: Six of the nine deadliest mass shootings in the United States since 2018 were by people who were 21 or younger, a shift from earlier decades.
content: WASHINGTON — The two young men accused of carrying out the massacres in Buffalo and Uvalde followed a familiar path: They legally bought semiautomatic rifles right after turning 18, posted images intended to display their strength and menace — and then turned those weapons on innocent people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Andersen
title: How Jack Welch Revolutionized the American Economy
description: David Gelles’s “The Man Who Broke Capitalism” examines the impact of one of the country’s most powerful chief executives.
content: In 2020 I published “Evil Geniuses,” a history of the ruinous transformation of the U.S. political economy since the 1970s by the right and the rich. So I was psyched to read “The Man Who Broke Capitalism.” It sounded like a perfect case-study companion to my wide-angle chronicle, a book by a longtime business reporter now at The New York Times, focusing on Jack Welch, “revered as the greatest C.E.O. of all time,” and General Electric, the company he ran from 1981 to 2001, “two decades that shaped the world we inhabit today.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adaobi Tricia Nwaubani
title: Guilty Until Proven Innocent: A Gay Refugee’s Confrontation With America
description: In his memoir, Edafe Okporo calls for a more “humane” treatment of asylum-seekers in the West.
content: ASYLUM A Memoir & Manifesto By Edafe Okporo
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrea Kendall-Taylor and Michael Kofman
title: Russia Is Down. But It’s Not Out.
description: Despite its failures in Ukraine, we shouldn’t write Russia off.
content: The war in Ukraine has undoubtedly tarnished Russia’s standing as a great power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: She Created SZA’s Floral Bikini. Could She Help Me With a Centerpiece?
description: A reporter learns about flower arranging from a botanical artist who wields a paintbrush.
content: When I was handed a stem of white orchids at a recent flower-arranging workshop at the Museum of Arts and Design in New York, my first impulse was to carefully carry it home, where I could put it in a vase all by itself and appreciate its blossoms for as long as they lasted. Instead, it seemed, we were to drag these precious beauties through paint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivek Shankar and Safak Timur
title: Now It’s Türkiye, Not Turkey, at the United Nations
description: The Turkish government wants the rest of the world to use the country’s own name for itself, and lose the association with a certain bird.
content: Turkey has changed its name at the United Nations, in the biggest push yet by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s government to get the rest of the world to call the country by its Turkish language name, Türkiye (tur-KEE-yeh).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The Fed’s vice chair says a coming pause in rate increases is unlikely.
description: Lael Brainard, the vice chair of the Federal Reserve, said another big rate increase in September might be appropriate if inflation did not moderate.
content: Lael Brainard, the Federal Reserve’s vice chair, suggested on Thursday that the central bank might make another large rate increase into September and threw cold water on the idea that policymakers might pause rate moves after the summer — signaling instead that they are intently focused on controlling too-high inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Coco Gauff Reaches French Open Final, Will Face Iga Swiatek
description: Gauff and Swiatek each advanced in their semifinals Thursday by winning in straight sets.
content: PARIS — It is easy to be in a rush when you reach the fourth round of Wimbledon at age 15, beating one of your idols, Venus Williams, in your opening match. It is easy to be in a hurry when the sponsors and the platform are already in place, and you have been hearing from experts and the voice inside your own head that you have what it takes to be a champion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Neptune Frost’ Review: Unanimous Gold Mine
description: An Afrofuturist fantasia about the state of the world and how to resist it.
content: Toward the end of the 20th century, the British novelist and critic John Berger insisted on the importance of what he called “pockets of resistance” — small-scale efforts to oppose global systems of domination and exploitation, or at least to imagine alternatives. The possibility of change, Berger suggested, could be found not in grand revolutionary movements but in local practices, including the making and contemplation of art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Sheryl Sandberg’s Legacy
description: Sandberg transformed digital advertising and was a voice on big issues, but she also denied problems and deflected blame.
content: It’s not clear how history will judge Sheryl Sandberg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: ‘Fortune Favors Lady Nikuko’ Review: Lovely Food, Bad Taste
description: A mother and adolescent daughter cook together, laugh together and face the usual generational struggles in a film with an unkind point of view.
content: The Japanese anime “Fortune Favors Lady Nikuko,” from the director Ayumu Watanabe and the creative producer Sanma Akashiya, is full of expressive, ravishing images, with a sumptuous watercolor style that renders every delicate sunrise and shimmering river a gorgeous and original vision. Of particular note is the food, which, despite being animated, looks utterly delicious: from French toast to fried noodles, from misuji (top blade Wagyu beef) to okonomiyaki (a kind of savory pancake), the meals this movie lingers over had my mouth watering. There is a sweet potato snack consumed in one scene that looks better than any sweet potato I’ve ever had in real life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yana Dlugy
title: Russia’s Chip Problem
description: Sanctions are hitting imports of microchips needed for Moscow’s advanced weapons.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Schmidt
title: Homeownership Remains the American Dream, Despite Challenges
description: A new survey reveals that nearly three-quarters of Americans place owning a home above career, family and college as a sign of prosperity.
content: Nearly three-quarters of Americans say owning a home is a higher measure of achievement than having a successful career, raising a family or earning a college degree, according to a new survey. But affordability remains a challenge for many of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Hollywood Stargirl’ Review: Starting Anew in La La Land
description: Julia Hart’s bubbly sequel picks up the story in summertime and reframes around Stargirl, a character who in the first movie was auxiliary by design.
content: After I read Jerry Spinelli’s best-selling Y.A. book “Stargirl,” titled for a quirky free spirit who spices up life for a diffident boy, I privately logged the name as a shorthand for stock female characters conjured to make men feel alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: The Actual Malice of the Johnny Depp Trial
description: In this post-#MeToo moment, misogyny and celebrity go hand in hand.
content: The Johnny Depp-Amber Heard defamation trial was, from gavel to gavel, a singularly baffling, unedifying and sad spectacle. Now that it has ended with the jury finding in favor of Depp on all questions and in favor of Heard on only one, it’s clear that the confusion was the point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Tamisiea
title: Giraffes May Be Long-Necked for Fights, Not Just Food
description: Evolutionary theories said giraffes developed their height to get to better eats, but ancestors may have gained the advantage through head-butting battles.
content: Since the days of Charles Darwin, the long necks of giraffes have been a textbook example of evolution. The theory goes that as giraffe ancestors competed for food, those with longer necks were able to reach higher leaves, getting a leg — or neck — up over shorter animals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Almost Famous,’ Now a Musical, Will Open on Broadway This Fall
description: The stage adaptation, with book and lyrics by Cameron Crowe and music and lyrics by Tom Kitt, will begin previews Sept. 13.
content: “Almost Famous,” Cameron Crowe’s rock ’n’ roll coming-of-age story, will make its pandemic-delayed trip to Broadway this fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: ‘She’s everyone’s queen’: Americans visit London for the jubilee’s pomp and pageantry.
description: They traveled from afar to celebrate Queen Elizabeth II’s 70-year reign.
content: For the last four years, Patricia Watts of Louisville, Ky., has been saving up for a trip to London. But it’s not just any vacation. For her, it’s a once-in-a-lifetime visit for Queen Elizabeth’s Platinum Jubilee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Mona Boshnaq
title: Queen Elizabeth’s Platinum Jubilee: Seven Decades in Photos
description: The images show the jubilee is above all a tribute to one of history’s great acts of constancy.
content: Queen Elizabeth II’s Platinum Jubilee, celebrating her 70 years on the British throne, is above all a tribute to one of history’s great acts of constancy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Diamanda Galás Gives Voice to Unbearable Pain, Once More
description: Revisiting “The Divine Punishment,” the first album in a trilogy addressing AIDS, and at work on new music, the singer and composer is still exploring isolation in her singular, startling way.
content: SAN DIEGO — It was 1984, and Diamanda Galás — then in her late 20s, a moaning, screaming singer who wrote music with titles like “The Litanies of Satan” and “Song From the Blood of Those Murdered” — was visiting a friend’s lover in a hospital in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: ‘You Are the Show’: A Hudson Valley Outpost of the Avant-Garde
description: PS21 presents work that challenges and invites, like performances by QDance, a Nigerian troupe whose leader says, “I am not your entertainment.”
content: CHATHAM, N.Y. — “There is no outside,” the Nigerian choreographer Qudus Onikeku said on Wednesday. He wasn’t referring to his surroundings: the open-air theater of PS21, set in the middle of 100 acres of orchard, meadow and woodlands in this Hudson Valley town. The inside/outside divide he meant was the one between the members of his company, QDance, and the public that had come to see them. “You are the show,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claudia Gryvatz Copquin and Jill P. Capuzzo
title: Homes for Sale on Long Island and in New Jersey
description: This week’s available properties are a four-bedroom house in Lloyd Neck, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Frenchtown, N.J.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly and David D. Kirkpatrick
title: House Panel Examining Jared Kushner Over Saudi Investment in New Firm
description: The House Oversight Committee is seeking documents related to the $2 billion investment by a Saudi fund in the private equity firm started by Mr. Kushner, Donald Trump’s son-in-law and former adviser.
content: A House committee said on Thursday that it was investigating whether Jared Kushner, former President Donald J. Trump’s son-in-law and former adviser, traded on his government position to land a $2 billion investment in his new private equity firm from a prominent Saudi Arabian wealth fund.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: Why Canada Races on Gun Policy When America Crawls
description: The speed of policymaking in Canada, and its frequent deadlock in the U.S., may come down to the rules of their political systems.
content: As Congress once more struggles through acrimonious and so far fruitless negotiations over gun reforms in the wake of a mass shooting, Americans may find themselves looking north in befuddlement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: How Are You Coping With Inflation?
description: We’d like to hear your story.
content: Nearly everyone is feeling the sting of inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: What Sheryl Sandberg’s ‘Lean In’ Has Meant to Women
description: The high-profile executive’s decision to leave Meta is also a moment to reflect on the impact of her best-selling book and philosophy about success in the workplace.
content: When Amy Bailey, a communications strategist, read “Lean In” by Sheryl Sandberg, the year was 2013. The #MeToo movement hadn’t yet ballooned, spotlighting the abuses women can face in the workplace. The term #girlboss wasn’t trending. And the question of how Facebook might affect democracy was not front and center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Doctors Transplant Ear of Human Cells, Made by 3-D Printer
description: 3DBio Therapeutics, a biotech company in Queens, said it had for the first time used 3-D printing to make a body part with a patient’s own cells.
content: A 20-year-old woman who was born with a small and misshapen right ear has received a 3-D printed ear implant made from her own cells, the manufacturer announced on Thursday. Independent experts said that the transplant, part of the first clinical trial of a successful medical application of this technology, was a stunning advance in the field of tissue engineering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘The Score’ Review: Songs in the Key of Heist
description: The singer-songwriter Johnny Flynn stars alongside Will Poulter and Naomi Ackie in an understated musical about two small-time crooks and a budding romance.
content: The title of this small-scale existentialist musical from the writer-director Malachi Smyth refers to the bag of cash two shabby crooks have driven to a sleepy stretch of England. It is also a nod to the fact that the day’s misadventures will be partly told in song.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: This weekend, our TV critic recommends a prehistoric nature documentary, a doc about a theater impresario and a new season of “Borgen.”
content: ‘Prehistoric Planet’
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, Jenny Gross and David F. Gallagher
title: The End of the Sandberg Era at Meta
description: Sheryl Sandberg is leaving at a time when Meta’s C.E.O. and founder, Mark Zuckerberg, has begun an aggressive effort to take it in a new direction.
content: In 2008, Sheryl Sandberg joined Facebook and soon became one of the most famous business leaders who was not a C.E.O. Sandberg, the chief operating officer of what is now Meta, announced yesterday that she would be leaving in the fall. The decision was her own, two of her employees told The Times. The timing of the announcement, about a half-hour before the close of trading, suggests that the company was not overly concerned about her exit’s impact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Friedman
title: How I Learned to Love Finishing Last
description: In a sport that rewards speed, sometimes it’s healthier to be the tortoise than to be the hare.
content: Many runners are driven by a desire to cross the finish line as fast as possible. I am driven by a desire to cross it before race organizers leave for the day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: ‘Enough, Enough’: Biden Calls On Lawmakers to Pass Gun Legislation
description: President Biden urged lawmakers to stop the sale of assault-style weapons, expand universal background checks and pass “red flag” laws after last month’s massacres in Texas and New York.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden demanded on Thursday that lawmakers respond to communities turned into “killing fields” by passing far-reaching limits on guns, calling on Congress to ban assault-style weapons, expand background checks and pass “red flag” laws after massacres in Texas and New York.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: June is Pride Month, so why not kick off your reading this week with a couple of relevant titles? James Kirchick’s “Secret City” explores the political and historical costs of closeted life in Washington, D.C., while Casey McQuiston’s Y.A. novel “I Kissed Shara Wheeler” tells the story of a queer teenage rebel investigating a popular girl’s disappearance. Also up: The account of a Reconstruction-era lynching in a small New York village, a look at Apple’s fate in the decade since Steve Jobs died, a study of the tense relationship between China and the West, and a frank and moving memoir by the actor Selma Blair. In fiction, we recommend new books by Ali Smith, Maggie Shipstead, Alexander Maksik and Ashleigh Bell Pedersen, along with new translations of a couple of classic novels by the great French writer Colette. Happy reading, everyone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Michael Forsythe
title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Yacht Company That Caters to Russian Elites
description: The Treasury Department also identified four yachts as being linked to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
content: WASHINGTON — The U.S. government leveled sanctions against a yacht management company and its owners, describing them as part of a corrupt system that allows Russian elites and President Vladimir V. Putin to enrich themselves, the Treasury Department announced on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Beach House, Meet Ocean View
description: A family’s new home in California was right on the shore, but only a major renovation would make the waves really visible.
content: When Ben and Rebekah Shaffer began looking for a second home that would feel like a world away from their daily reality in Silicon Valley, they weren’t sure about which direction to take.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: ‘MJ’: Dancing the Pain, and Dancing the Pain Away
description: What is the role of choreography on Broadway? Two musicals, “MJ” and “A Strange Loop,” shed light on the dancing body.
content: Don’t get me wrong: The musical “MJ” is a misfire on so many levels that it’s hard to know where to begin. “Thriller” looks like a scene out of “Cats.” The segment showing Michael Jackson’s dance influences — the Nicholas Brothers, Fred Astaire, Bob Fosse — is so poor in terms of skill level that I felt sorry for dance, the art form. Irritatingly, yet predictably, the show, directed by the ballet choreographer Christopher Wheeldon, has been nominated for 10 Tony Awards. It will run for ages. Michael Jackson — for all his flaws — is still Michael Jackson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: BAM’s Next Wave Festival Returns With an Ivo Van Hove Production
description: The American premiere of the brutal play “A Little Life,” a drag-infused Hamlet and an immersive celestial installation highlight the festival’s latest iteration.
content: The Brooklyn Academy of Music’s artistic director, David Binder, who is programming the 13 shows for the Next Wave Festival, is mixing “incredible light” and darkness, he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘The Phantom of the Open’ Review: ‘The World’s Worst Golfer’ Wins Laughs
description: Inspired by Maurice Flitcroft’s stunningly bad results at the 1976 British Open, this comedy plays with a genre in which underdogs so often triumph.
content: The British comedy “The Phantom of the Open” — about a working man’s dreams of golf glory — features a few dreamlike sequences that suggest the director, Craig Roberts, is a fan of the 1946 fantasy romance, “Stairway to Heaven,” especially when a tiny golfer circles a golf ball the size of the moon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: ‘The Wire’ Stands Alone
description: After 20 years, the classic drama is much praised and rarely imitated. For a series based on the idea that institutions don’t change, that’s fitting.
content: When critics get to assessing a classic TV show, we have a weird tendency to turn into evolutionary biologists. We pull out the old television family tree and gauge the series’s achievement by how many branches we can trace back to it — how many series modeled one or another aspect on it. “Dragnet,” “The Simpsons,” “Lost” — you shall know them by their copycats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Tallying the Costs, Shirts and All, of Missing the World Cup
description: Failure to qualify for Qatar has condemned Nigeria to a humbling summer instead of months of World Cup hype. Then there’s the fate of its famous jersey.
content: In those initial moments of agony in March after Nigeria was eliminated from qualification for this year’s World Cup, the most immediate thoughts of Amaju Pinnick, the president of Nigeria’s soccer federation, were of the disappointment being felt by his 200 million countrymen in Africa’s most populous nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson, John Ismay and Edward Wong
title: U.S. Technology, a Longtime Tool for Russia, Becomes a Vulnerability
description: Global restrictions on sending advanced technology to Russia are hampering the country’s military capacity, U.S. officials say, though Russia has stockpiled American equipment for years.
content: WASHINGTON — With magnifying glasses, screwdrivers and a delicate touch from a soldering gun, two men from an investigative group that tracks weapons pried open Russian munitions and equipment that had been captured across Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: Brad Raffensperger testifies for Fulton County grand jury.
description: ATLANTA — Brad Raffensperger, Georgia’s secretary of state, testified on Thursday before a Fulton County special grand jury as part of an investigation into former President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election results in the state.
content: ATLANTA — Brad Raffensperger, Georgia’s secretary of state, testified on Thursday before a Fulton County special grand jury as part of an investigation into former President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election results in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Jodi Kantor
title: Weinstein’s Sex Crime Conviction, a Milestone for #MeToo, Is Upheld
description: New York judges approved testimony from women who said they were abused by Harvey Weinstein. The disgraced former producer, awaiting another trial in Los Angeles, is serving 23 years.
content: A New York appeals court on Thursday upheld Harvey Weinstein’s 2020 conviction on felony sex crimes, increasing the likelihood that the disgraced movie producer will serve a significant portion of his 23-year sentence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lena Wilson
title: ‘Watcher’ Review: Terror, at a Glance
description: In Chloe Okuno’s taut first feature, a woman is convinced a man is watching and possibly even following her.
content: While the film theorist Laura Mulvey may be best known for her concept of the male gaze, she has used another evocative term in her writing to illustrate her point: “to-be-looked-at-ness.” This gestures to the ways in which women — particularly onscreen — have historically been destined for display, intentional objects of erotic pleasure. “Watcher” follows Julia, an ex-actress played superbly by Maika Monroe, who is suffocating under the weight of her to-be-looked-at-ness. And not just because she believes a creep is surveilling her apartment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: ‘What Was the Point?’: Freed After 9 Years, Refugees Learn to Live Again
description: Australia suddenly released migrants held under its tough approach to asylum seekers. While the worst of their ordeal is over, their future remains precarious.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — The men mill around the front of the weathered motel, blinking in the sunlight, not sure what to do with themselves. Around their feet are suitcases and large plastic bags holding everything they own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Barnard
title: Mutual Aid Takes New Form as Baby Formula Shortage Continues
description: Demand for breast milk is rising with formula in short supply, but the New York Milk Bank has also seen an increase in offers to donate. Also, one family’s journey to find a residential school for an autistic teenager.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll look at a growing movement in New York City and around the country to help mitigate the impact of a baby formula shortage by donating breast milk. And we’ll learn about one of the many families of autistic teenagers who have struggled to care for them during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: We’ve Got to Stop Requiring Parking Everywhere
description: Mandatory parking rules make housing more expensive. California’s legislature should undo them.
content: There are more registered vehicles in California than there are adult human beings. This isn’t especially anomalous — vehicles outnumber people who can drive them in much of the United States — but the mismatch is particularly absurd in the nation’s most populous and most car-obsessed state, where people and cars have long been locked in a largely invisible battle for the same precious resource: places to park themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joyce Cohen
title: Exploring the Classic Co-ops of Brooklyn With Less Than $800,000 to Spend. Which Home Did They Choose?
description: Alarmed by horror stories of construction defects in new buildings, and limited to a 10 percent down payment, a young couple tried to find a two-bedroom in decent condition. Here’s what they saw.
content: Alarmed by horror stories of construction defects in new buildings, and limited to a 10 percent down payment, a young couple tried to find a two-bedroom in decent condition. Here’s what they saw.

title: What’s in Our Queue? Tiny Desk Concerts and More
description: I’m an editor on The Times’s Culture desk. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.
content: I’m an editor on The Times’s Culture desk. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.

author: By Megan Specia
title: Marking the Queen’s 70 Years on the Throne
description: Central London was thronged with revelers on Thursday for the Platinum Jubilee celebrations to mark seven decades since Queen Elizabeth II ascended to the throne.
